title: Everton back to winning ways as Dominic Calvert-Lewin's quickfire double is too much for Sheffield Wednesday in Carabao Cup
text:
Dominic Calvert-Lewin scored both of Everton's goals - Getty Images Europe

Sheffield Wednesday 0 Everton 2

Dominic Calvert-Lewin grew up just over a mile away from Sheffield Wednesday’s home ground but has always been a Blade and sliced the Championship club apart on his return to his home city.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

Calvert-Lewin is the teenage prodigy who has never quite become the player he was supposed to be at Everton. Signed for £1.5 million as a 19-year-old, in 2016, after just 12 appearances for Sheffield United, he has been a more effective player for England’s Under-20s and 21s than he has for his club.

There is talent there, but he managed just eight goals for Everton last term and has failed to convince he lead the line for a club that is still searching for an effective replacement for Romelu Lukaku, two years on from his departure to Manchester United.

Still just 22, this was a timely reminder of what Calvert-Lewin, who attended the Forge Valley School five minutes’ drive from Hillsborough, can do

“Dominic was the striker who has started more time on the pitch with me this season,” said a relieved Everton manager Marco Silva. “It was important for him to score twice and in the important part of the game, three goals in his last games is good for his confidence. Let’s hope he can continue this way.”

The first finish was emphatic, taking down Djibril Sidibe’s cross field pass with a delicate touch, he steadied himself and thumped a ferocious shot past Wednesday goalkeeper Cameron Dawson.

Calvert-Lewin grabbed his second moments later. Bernard and Alex Iwobi combined down the left, with the latter pulling the ball back across goal, where Everton’s number 9 stretched out a leg to convert.

Story continues

Wednesday tried to make a game of it and Sam Winnall, who also failed to beat Jordan Pickford one-on-one in the first half, put a free header over the bar from a free kick, but Everton were comfortable.

Match details

Sheffield Wednesday (4-4-2): Dawson 7; Odubajo 7, Iorfa 6, Thorniley 6, Fox 6; Reach 6, Luongo 5, Pelupessy 6, Murphy 4 (Harris 59), Winnall 4 (Rhodes 64), Nuhiu 5 (Fletcher 70)

Subs not used: Jones, Palmer, Lee, FBannan



Everton (4-2-3-1): Pickford 6; Holgate 6, Mina 7, Sidibe 7, Digne 6; Delph 7 (Schneiderlin 90+1), Davies 7; Richarlison 5 (Walcott 67), Iwobi 7, Bernard 7 (Sigurdsson 76); Calvert-Lewin 8

Subs not used: Lossl, Keane, Coleman, Kean.

Booked: Delph





Referee: Jeremy Simpson

Attendance: 21,485
description: Dominic Calvert-Lewin grew up just over a mile away from Sheffield Wednesday’s home ground but has always been a Blade and sliced the Championship club apart on his return to his home city.
